text:
Washington students plan to sell green and white cupcakes in large ad small boxes.

The students at Washington school have 40 white cupcakes to package.

If they put then in large boxes, how many green cupcakes will they need?

If they put them in small boxes of cupcakes how many green cupcakes will they need?

Students decide to so a walking backward race. They do a few trials. They find that the average middle school student can walk 1/4 of a mile backward in 6 minutes.

The students schedule the race for 30 minutes. Whoever walks the farthest is the winner.

How many miles would the average middle school student cover in this amount of time? Explain your reasoning

Hank is very excited about using the algebraic expression 3N to express multiples of 3, so he makes up a new game, Algebra Connections. He uses clue cards with algebraic expressions and equations involving factors and multiples. The players take turns deciding if there is one more than one number that makes the expression true. N is a whole number.

For each card, what are the possible whole numbers for N?

In prior grades, we have been studying numbers. In this unit, we will continue to look at some of the important properties of numbers in a more general way. Whole numbers have interesting properties and structures:

  • Some numbers can be divided by many numbers.
  • Other numbers can be divided by only a few numbers.
  • Some pairs of numbers have lots of factors in common.
  • Some pairs of numbers share only one factor in common.
  • Numbers can be written as the sum of numbers.
  • Some numbers can be written as products or sums of products.

Recognizing and expressing important properties and structures of numbers more generally is called algebraic reasoning. We used algebra and algebraic reasoning to represent and explore the relationship between two variables in the Variables and Patterns unit.

In this unit, we will explore some interesting patterns. We will find ways to express these patterns more generally using algebraic expressions and equations. When we predict what we think will happen in a mathematical situation, we are making a conjecture. A conjecture is our best guess about an observed pattern or relationship. We will use these ideas about the properties and structure of numbers to solve some interesting problems.

As we work on the problems in this unit, ask yourself questions about problem situations that involve number:

  • In what ways is the multiplicative structure of number useful?
  • In what ways is the additive structure of number useful?
  • When might it be useful to write a number in factored form or as a sum or both?
  • What are the advantages of expressing number patterns more generally?

Investigation 1

Generalizing Factor and Multiple Patterns: Algebraic Reasoning

In prior grades, we learned about numbers and some of their interesting properties.

What are some interesting things you know about whole numbers?

Isabella remembers a project in which she had to write a story about her favorite number. The story included mathematical facts about the number and connections between the number and the world. Her favorite number is 12. Her project included the following information.
What is your favorite number? What do you know about it?
Isabella noticed many ways to represent the number 12. These representations are called numeric expressions. Since they all represent 12, they are equivalent expressions.
